values.title: Use c++11 to eliminate boost dependency

content.raw: I believe the dependency on boost/random.hpp can be elminated with [c++11 random number improvements](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C++11#Extensible_random_number_facility). The other dependency is boost::math::round, and I believe this is now [std::round](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/numeric/math/round) in c++11.
content.html: I believe the dependency on boost/random.hpp can be elminated with c++11 random number improvements. The other dependency is boost::math::round, and I believe this is now std::round in c++11.

content.raw: It's pretty clever the way the Matrix and Vector classes share code across different types. I wonder if we considered using templates instead? I'm not suggesting that we change; I'm just wondering if templates were considered and what are the pros/cons.

content.raw: There's an overloaded operator for multiplying Matrix3 with Matrix4, which seems weird to me. I suspect there's a useful reason for this, but we should document what it does because it's not standard linear algebra.

content.raw:
Eigen provides Vector, Matrix, Quaternion, and [Affine transform](http://eigen.tuxfamily.org/dox/group__TutorialGeometry.html) (pose) types. We should consider using it. (Migrated from [gazebo issue 929](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/929/consider-using-eigen-to-improve-math)).

It looks like it is portable. One major thing we are missing is the ability to use arbitrary matrices (necessary for Jacobians). Eigen supports arbitrarily-sized matrices, as well as sparse matrices.
content.html:
Eigen provides Vector, Matrix, Quaternion, and Affine transform (pose) types. We should consider using it. (Migrated from gazebo issue 929).

It looks like it is portable. One major thing we are missing is the ability to use arbitrary matrices (necessary for Jacobians). Eigen supports arbitrarily-sized matrices, as well as sparse matrices.

content.raw:
Hi,

just a question/suggestion.
A quick inspection of the code reveals that no SSE or similar vectorization was used.
Being this library a potential building block of several robotic components (kinematics, graphics, dynamics, etc.) I wonder why you need to build from scratch yet another implementation when Bullet 3 has a vectorized one.
Why aren't you using Eigen?
This is of course an observation that I would give to anyone writing somethin like Matrix4x4.h...  ;)

Kind regards

Davide

values.title: Lines (line segments) have an implicit direction

content.raw:
The current implementation of `Line2` (which are actually line segments, i.e. not infinite) has implicit start and end points. 

The [equality operator](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/b14fb1895d109070408cbdf914566be2240fa6e0/include/ignition/math/Line2.hh?at=default#cl-272) for example checks if `lineA->pts[0] == lineB->pts[0] && lineA->pts[1] == lineB->pts[1]`, but not if `lineA->pts[0] == lineB->pts[1] && lineA->pts[1] == lineB->pts[0]`.

Is that done on purpose, that is, we want the start and end points of a line to mean something, or is it something which was overlooked?
content.html:
The current implementation of Line2 (which are actually line segments, i.e. not infinite) has implicit start and end points.

The equality operator for example checks if lineA->pts[0] == lineB->pts[0] && lineA->pts[1] == lineB->pts[1], but not if lineA->pts[0] == lineB->pts[1] && lineA->pts[1] == lineB->pts[0].

Is that done on purpose, that is, we want the start and end points of a line to mean something, or is it something which was overlooked?

values.title: Wrong default build type on Windows

content.raw:
The default build type on Windows is set to `Debug`. I believe is should be `Release` following the same convention we use in `Gazebo` or `sdformat` for example.

There's a small patch in [this branch](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branches/compare/build_release_win%0Ddefault#commits) waiting for the next round of pull requests.

content.raw:
There are several places in templated functions where scalar values are passed by reference instead of value ([Vector4 constructor](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/12519225abe49c1b59a6768800470e5c009f3694/include/ignition/math/Vector4.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Vector4.hh-48) for example). @iche033 [recently pointed out](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2066/pimplize-light-class#comment-13015303) that it is often better to pass primitive types by value rather than by reference ([reference 1](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10770410/reasons-to-not-pass-simple-types-by-reference) and [reference 2](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14013139/is-it-counter-productive-to-pass-primitive-types-by-reference)).

We can evaluate this sometime if we set up some performance tests. I've marked this as a minor issue for the time being.
content.html:
There are several places in templated functions where scalar values are passed by reference instead of value (Vector4 constructor for example). @iche033 recently pointed out that it is often better to pass primitive types by value rather than by reference (reference 1 and reference 2).

We can evaluate this sometime if we set up some performance tests. I've marked this as a minor issue for the time being.

The SignalStats class uses the pimpl idiom, but the memory allocated in the constructor is never properly deallocated. Furthermore the copy constructor is used in the code (for example in [1]) but the default copy constructor is used, so multiple `SignalStats` objects are pointing to the same SignalStatsPrivate struct.

This commit caused undefined behavior or even assert for sorting Vector3 62370199526c199423ed81c9bc58d0913eaeca04, e.g.:

v1 = (1.0, 2.0, 3.0), v2 = (3.0, 2.0, 1.0)

Probably would be better to use something like this:

bool operator<(const Vector3d &lhs, const Vector3d &rhs) {
  if (lhs.X() < rhs.X())
    return true;
  if (lhs.X() > rhs.X())
    return false;
  return lhs.Y() < rhs.Y();
}

values.title: Allow Vector3::Equal to use vector of tolerances

content.html:
Curently, the Vector3::Equal with tolerance check uses a single tolerance for all three elements.

Proposal to extend it by adding:

      /// \brief Equality test with tolerance vector.
      /// \param[in] _v the vector to compare to
      /// \param[in] _tol a vector containing equality tolerances.
      /// \return true if the elements of the vectors are equal within
      /// the tolerence specified by _tol.
      public: bool Equal(const Vector3 &_v, const Vector3 &_tol) const
      {
        return equal<T>(this->data[0], _v[0], _tol[0])
            && equal<T>(this->data[1], _v[1], _tol[1])
            && equal<T>(this->data[2], _v[2], _tol[2]);
      }

Based on discussion in pull request #82, we might need to extend it further with:

      public: bool NumericallyEqual(const Vector3 &_v, const Vector3 &_tol) const;
      public: bool RelativelyEqual(const Vector3 &_v, const Vector3 &_tol) const;

values.title: Add Numerically Equal and Relatively Equal comparisons in math helper class

content.raw:
[Current comparison strategy math::equal](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/bde3d3bba851e6aa196a654c013f492d8b344dae/include/ignition/math/Helpers.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Helpers.hh-327) is using primitive absolute magnitude comparison. This may not be sufficient in some cases, for example where relative magnitudes are large, or the values being compared border numerical precision boundaries. 

Per @sherm1 recommendation in pull request #82, we should add `math::numericallyEqual` and `math::relativelyEqual`.

Also, see issue #42 for extension to Vector3 class.
content.html:
Current comparison strategy math::equal is using primitive absolute magnitude comparison. This may not be sufficient in some cases, for example where relative magnitudes are large, or the values being compared border numerical precision boundaries.

Per @sherm1 recommendation in pull request #82, we should add math::numericallyEqual and math::relativelyEqual.

Also, see issue #42 for extension to Vector3 class.

content.raw:
The private `static GeneratorType*` class variable [ignition::math::Rand::randGenerator](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/be7428eb46b5aea2690fcbb518dcdcbfbe8063ee/include/ignition/math/Rand.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Rand.hh-77) is [allocated with `new`](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/be7428eb46b5aea2690fcbb518dcdcbfbe8063ee/src/Rand.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Rand.cc-38) but is never `delete`d so I think it will leak.

Since it is a private static variable, I wonder if we can change it to a `std::unique_ptr` without breaking ABI?
content.html:
The private static GeneratorType* class variable ignition::math::Rand::randGenerator is allocated with new but is never deleted so I think it will leak.

Since it is a private static variable, I wonder if we can change it to a std::unique_ptr without breaking ABI?

content.raw:
It looks like on ARMv7, the "long double" type is the same as the "double" type.  This means that the Szudzek pair function (Pair() and Unpair()) don't work as expected, and the unit tests for large numbers fail.  I'm seeing the tests in src/Helpers_TEST.cc:411 fail quite badly while building: see "build.log" at http://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=14931350 (the log is quite big due to the number of tests that fail)

Attached is a patch that adds an \_\_arm\_\_ check to the _MSC_VER check that downgrades the PairInput and PairOutput data types and blocks the large number unit tests.

values.title: Possible to end up with a finite box with EXTENT_NULL

content.raw:
All boxes get [initialized](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/ac3e1c68e7ec682b6425d10ac62fd0c357fdbfed/include/ignition/math/BoxPrivate.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#BoxPrivate.hh-41) with `EXTENT_NULL`. So it's possible that one sets the box minimum and maximum directly, and the box will still not have `EXTENT_FINITE`.

See [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2491/fix-2089-incorrect-model-visual-and/diff) gazebo pull request for an example of the issues this might cause.
content.html:
All boxes get initialized with EXTENT_NULL. So it's possible that one sets the box minimum and maximum directly, and the box will still not have EXTENT_FINITE.

See this gazebo pull request for an example of the issues this might cause.

values.title: Macros vs static const values in Helpers.hh

content.raw:
There are a bunch of macros defined in Helpers.hh (like [IGN_DBL_MAX](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/93361a84c4fdb8a36b6852452e04361b439590cc/include/ignition/math/Helpers.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Helpers.hh-31)), but there are also static const variables (like [ignition::math::NAN_D](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/93361a84c4fdb8a36b6852452e04361b439590cc/include/ignition/math/Helpers.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Helpers.hh-210)). I assume the static const values are nicer than macros. Should we create matching static const values and point the macros there? Then maybe someday we could deprecate / remove the macros?

cc: @nkoenig
content.html:
There are a bunch of macros defined in Helpers.hh (like IGN_DBL_MAX), but there are also static const variables (like ignition::math::NAN_D). I assume the static const values are nicer than macros. Should we create matching static const values and point the macros there? Then maybe someday we could deprecate / remove the macros?

cc: @nkoenig

values.title: Brainstorming: strong(er) typed primitives with more semantic

content.raw:
Hi,
recently in the C++ community we can notice a tendency toward strong types to avoid bugs at compilation time.
Good examples are Boost::units and std::chrono.

In std::chrono there is a strong separation in terms of types between timepoint and duration.
Some operations are permitted while others aren't; casting must be explicit.

for instance:

     timepoint +/- duration = timepoint
     duration +/- duration = duration
     timepoint - timepoint = duration
     timepoint + timepoint = won't compile

The same approach in terms of strong semantic can be applied to types such as Point3D/Vector3D or CoordinateFrame/HomogenousTransform3D (we might find better names).

     Point3D +/- Vector3D = Point3D
     Vector3D +/- Vector3D = Vector3D
     Point3D - Point3D = Vector3D
     Point3D + Point3D = won't compile

I believe that this enhancement would be very interesting and it is the typical "zero-overhead abstraction" that is so popular nowadays.

What do you think?
content.html:

In std::chrono there is a strong separation in terms of types between timepoint and duration. Some operations are permitted while others aren't; casting must be explicit.

for instance:

 timepoint +/- duration = timepoint
 duration +/- duration = duration
 timepoint - timepoint = duration
 timepoint + timepoint = won't compile

The same approach in terms of strong semantic can be applied to types such as Point3D/Vector3D or CoordinateFrame/HomogenousTransform3D (we might find better names).

 Point3D +/- Vector3D = Point3D
 Vector3D +/- Vector3D = Vector3D
 Point3D - Point3D = Vector3D
 Point3D + Point3D = won't compile

I believe that this enhancement would be very interesting and it is the typical "zero-overhead abstraction" that is so popular nowadays.

What do you think?

content.raw:
The Box class is axis-aligned, but it might be useful to define boxes which aren't. For example, right now I'd like to use such a box to check if it contains a 3D point.

It looks like such a thing is not very common. Eigen for example only offers an [`AlignedBox`](https://eigen.tuxfamily.org/dox/classEigen_1_1AlignedBox.html). 

A few implementation options I can think of:

1. Add a pose to the current box class, which entails taking the pose into account in several of its methods.
2. Add methods to the current Box class which accept a pose, and only those methods do pose-related calculations
3. Create a new class which has pose.
content.html:
The Box class is axis-aligned, but it might be useful to define boxes which aren't. For example, right now I'd like to use such a box to check if it contains a 3D point.

It looks like such a thing is not very common. Eigen for example only offers an AlignedBox.

A few implementation options I can think of:

  1. Add a pose to the current box class, which entails taking the pose into account in several of its methods.
  2. Add methods to the current Box class which accept a pose, and only those methods do pose-related calculations
  3. Create a new class which has pose.

values.title: Consider adding Color and Time classes

content.raw:
Consider moving [`gazebo::common::Color`](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/56be256c4ba911e9ffb6fece23b0c51170f6dbdf/gazebo/common/Color.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default) / `ignition::common::Color` and [`gazebo::common::Time`](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/56be256c4ba911e9ffb6fece23b0c51170f6dbdf/gazebo/common/Time.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default) / `ignition::common::Time` here. 

While it can be argued that these are not strictly "math" concepts, we could draw a parallel to existing ignition math classes such as [`Temperature`](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/113/temperature-class/diff). They're basically different ways of storing numbers which have special semantics.

On a less important note, this could also benefit ign-msgs, which already depends on ignition-math and could provide [conversions](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/src/50124cfffb91edb73f471b37c807d3680949775c/include/ignition/msgs/Utility.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Utility.hh-30) for the `time` and `color` messages.
content.html:
Consider moving gazebo::common::Color / ignition::common::Color and gazebo::common::Time / ignition::common::Time here.

While it can be argued that these are not strictly "math" concepts, we could draw a parallel to existing ignition math classes such as Temperature. They're basically different ways of storing numbers which have special semantics.

On a less important note, this could also benefit ign-msgs, which already depends on ignition-math and could provide conversions for the time and color messages.

content.raw:
Currently, ignition::math::Spline straightforward implementation has a number of caveats and limitations:

1. No control over spline point tangents.
2. No support for tangent (or m-derivative) interpolation.
3. No support for arc length computation.
4. Parameterization works great for evenly distributed
    points but leads to velocity changes when this isn't the case.

I've opened a [proposal PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/161/spline-improvements-proposal/diff) addressing 1, 2 and 3. Number 4 is harder, and attempts to transition to an arc length parameterization have been unsuccessfull so far (as you'll notice by the dummy implementation that the parameterization class now has). 

I'd love to hear some feedback.
content.html:
Currently, ignition::math::Spline straightforward implementation has a number of caveats and limitations:

  1. No control over spline point tangents.
  2. No support for tangent (or m-derivative) interpolation.
  3. No support for arc length computation.
  4. Parameterization works great for evenly distributed points but leads to velocity changes when this isn't the case.

I've opened a proposal PR addressing 1, 2 and 3. Number 4 is harder, and attempts to transition to an arc length parameterization have been unsuccessfull so far (as you'll notice by the dummy implementation that the parameterization class now has).

I'd love to hear some feedback.

content.raw:
I stumbled upon a problem with ``Box`` when using the default constructor, and subsequently setting the box min/max with the ``Min()`` and ``Max()`` functions, e.g.

```cpp
ignition::math::Box b;
b.Min() = something;
b.Max() = somethingElse;
```

The default constructor doesn't initialize ``BoxPrivate::extent`` to ``EXTENT_FINITE``, as the other constructors would, e.g. the constructor taking two vectors:

```cpp
//////////////////////////////////////////////////                              
Box::Box(const Vector3d &_vec1, const Vector3d &_vec2)                          
: dataPtr(new BoxPrivate)                                                       
{                                                                               
  this->dataPtr->extent = BoxPrivate::EXTENT_FINITE;                            
  ...
}     
```
So in my opinion it should be documented that to have a valid ``Box``, one needs to use any constructor but the default one, *or* we should add a method ``Box::Set(const ignition::Vector3d &min, ignition::Vector3d &max)`` which also sets the extent to EXTENT_FINITE, and document at ``Min()`` and ``Max()`` that if these functions are used to initialize the box, one would have to additionally ensure the box was previously correctly initialized with a suitable constructor, or that the new ``Set()`` function should be used instead. 

Problems arising if the extent is not initialized become clear with the ``Box::operator+=``:

```cpp
//////////////////////////////////////////////////                              
const Box &Box::operator+=(const Box &_b)                                       
{                                                                               
  if (this->dataPtr->extent != BoxPrivate::EXTENT_NULL)                         
  {                                                                             
    this->dataPtr->min.Min(_b.dataPtr->min);                                    
    this->dataPtr->max.Max(_b.dataPtr->max);                                    
  }                                                                             
  else                                                                          
  {                                                                             
    this->dataPtr->min = _b.dataPtr->min;                                       
    this->dataPtr->max = _b.dataPtr->max;                                       
    this->dataPtr->extent = _b.dataPtr->extent;                                 
  }                                                                             
  return *this;                                                                 
}      
```
An invalid box will never be added correctly to other boxes.

I noticed this in Gazebo, where ``gazebo::physics::Link::BoundingBox()`` uses this operator.

I would propose to update the documentation and add a ``Set()`` function as suggested. If you agree, or have other suggestions, let me know and I can send a PR for this.
content.html:
I stumbled upon a problem with Box when using the default constructor, and subsequently setting the box min/max with the Min() and Max() functions, e.g.

ignition::math::Box b;
b.Min() = something;
b.Max() = somethingElse;

The default constructor doesn't initialize BoxPrivate::extent to EXTENT_FINITE, as the other constructors would, e.g. the constructor taking two vectors:

//////////////////////////////////////////////////                              
Box::Box(const Vector3d &_vec1, const Vector3d &_vec2)                          
: dataPtr(new BoxPrivate)                                                       
{                                                                               
  this->dataPtr->extent = BoxPrivate::EXTENT_FINITE;                            
  ...
}

So in my opinion it should be documented that to have a valid Box, one needs to use any constructor but the default one, or we should add a method Box::Set(const ignition::Vector3d &min, ignition::Vector3d &max) which also sets the extent to EXTENT_FINITE, and document at Min() and Max() that if these functions are used to initialize the box, one would have to additionally ensure the box was previously correctly initialized with a suitable constructor, or that the new Set() function should be used instead.

Problems arising if the extent is not initialized become clear with the Box::operator+=:

//////////////////////////////////////////////////                              
const Box &Box::operator+=(const Box &_b)                                       
{                                                                               
  if (this->dataPtr->extent != BoxPrivate::EXTENT_NULL)                         
  {                                                                             
    this->dataPtr->min.Min(_b.dataPtr->min);                                    
    this->dataPtr->max.Max(_b.dataPtr->max);                                    
  }                                                                             
  else                                                                          
  {                                                                             
    this->dataPtr->min = _b.dataPtr->min;                                       
    this->dataPtr->max = _b.dataPtr->max;                                       
    this->dataPtr->extent = _b.dataPtr->extent;                                 
  }                                                                             
  return *this;                                                                 
}

An invalid box will never be added correctly to other boxes.

I noticed this in Gazebo, where gazebo::physics::Link::BoundingBox() uses this operator.

I would propose to update the documentation and add a Set() function as suggested. If you agree, or have other suggestions, let me know and I can send a PR for this.

values.title: ignition::math::Vector3: operator [] does not return reference

content.raw:
``math::Vector3::operator[]`` does not return a reference, which sometimes can be useful. For example, as it is, we cannot use the operator for writing the i'th value conveniently in loops, e.g.

```
#!c++

for (int i=0; i<2; ++i)
  v[i] = ...
```

instead, we have to use X()/Y()/Z() functions.

Is this intended, or would it be a good idea to return a reference from the operator instead? I can submit a PR for this if everyone agrees.

See also related [Gazebo issue 2713](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2713).
content.html:
math::Vector3::operator[] does not return a reference, which sometimes can be useful. For example, as it is, we cannot use the operator for writing the i'th value conveniently in loops, e.g.

for (int i=0; i<2; ++i)
  v[i] = ...

instead, we have to use X()/Y()/Z() functions.

Is this intended, or would it be a good idea to return a reference from the operator instead? I can submit a PR for this if everyone agrees.

See also related Gazebo issue 2713.

values.title: Consider removing HasLoop() / EnsureNoLoop() from Spline

content.raw:
After approaching the problem that gave birth to the implementation of `HasLoop()` and `EnsureNoLoop()` from a different angle (by using other polynomials to generate the curves) we realized that, instead of checking for loops in Hermite splines, it may be a better option to use a different type of splines from the start (one that can't have loops by definition). In particular, using pchip splines has proven to be a successful approach in avoiding loops altogether, while also ensuring monotonicity and convexity in each curve piece. If we also consider that:

- ign-math-3 is still at an early stage, hence the chance of affecting an existing use of `HasLoop()` / `EnsureNoLoop()` is low.
- `HasLoop()` / `EnsureNoLoop()` only supports 2D splines (this was a known restriction that we planned to address in the future) and the concept of a 3D loop in an spline may be debatable.

we propose to remove these methods form `Spline` and instead think of extending ign-math-3 with bezier and pchip curves opportunistically as we need them.

@caguero what do you think?
content.html:
After approaching the problem that gave birth to the implementation of HasLoop() and EnsureNoLoop() from a different angle (by using other polynomials to generate the curves) we realized that, instead of checking for loops in Hermite splines, it may be a better option to use a different type of splines from the start (one that can't have loops by definition). In particular, using pchip splines has proven to be a successful approach in avoiding loops altogether, while also ensuring monotonicity and convexity in each curve piece. If we also consider that:

  • ign-math-3 is still at an early stage, hence the chance of affecting an existing use of HasLoop() / EnsureNoLoop() is low.
  • HasLoop() / EnsureNoLoop() only supports 2D splines (this was a known restriction that we planned to address in the future) and the concept of a 3D loop in an spline may be debatable.

we propose to remove these methods form Spline and instead think of extending ign-math-3 with bezier and pchip curves opportunistically as we need them.

@caguero what do you think?

values.title: Add function to update the axis-aligned box by a transform

content.raw:
It would beuseful to have a function which updates the axis-aligned box coordinates/dimensions when it is transformed. 

For example:

```
#!c++


ignition::math::Box UpdateAABB(const ignition::math::Box &_a, const ignition::math::Matrix4d &_m)
```

We could use the function as described in the book *real-time collision detection* by Christer Ericson, v. 1, p. 86, function *UpdateAABB*. It has been implemented in Gazebo's [gazebo/physics/dart/DARTCollision.cc](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/c1c50dc2390e9b1fc168ca41a501db5b57119212/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTCollision.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#DARTCollision.cc-157). It would be nice to add this function to ignition math.
content.html:
It would beuseful to have a function which updates the axis-aligned box coordinates/dimensions when it is transformed.

For example:

ignition::math::Box UpdateAABB(const ignition::math::Box &_a, const ignition::math::Matrix4d &_m)

We could use the function as described in the book real-time collision detection by Christer Ericson, v. 1, p. 86, function UpdateAABB. It has been implemented in Gazebo's gazebo/physics/dart/DARTCollision.cc. It would be nice to add this function to ignition math.

In order to use std::move semantics in c++ (like assignment of unique_ptr's), objects need to have move constructor and move assignment operators defined (also known as the rule of 5. This lets you do things like this:

std::unique_ptr<math::Pose3d> ptr1, ptr2;
ptr1.reset(new math::Pose3d);
ptr2 = ptr1;

but that doesn't currently work because we aren't following the rule of 5 for many of our classes. I mention this because I was trying to use it in a gazebo plugin and it didn't work. I've added some statements to unit tests in 90dce39 that illustrate this failure to compile.

values.title: Frustum incorrectly reports that it contains a box

content.html:
The frustum class appears to incorrectly report that it contains a box in the following example.

      const ignition::math::Vector3d corner1(2.2, -0.5, 0);
      const ignition::math::Vector3d corner2(3.2, 0.5, 1);
      ignition::math::Box bb(corner1, corner2);
      const double near = 0.55;
      const double far = 2.5;
      const double horizontalFieldOfView = 1.05;
      const double aspectRatio = 1.8;
      const ignition::math::Pose3d fPose(0, 0, 2, 0, 0, 0);
      ignition::math::Frustum frustum(near, far, horizontalFieldOfView, aspectRatio, fPose);
      if (frustum.Contains(bb))
      {
        std::cerr << "Oops, frustum should have returned false! \n";
      }

Here's a side view of the example at y=0

values.title: Graph::InDegree and IncidentsTo are slower than OutDegree and IncidentsFrom

content.raw:
The `Graph` class uses an [adjacency list](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/9e81045e43342db8a910dfe76729d0b22ffa4e68/include/ignition/math/graph/Graph.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Graph.hh-688:693) internally to assist with computations. This is stored internally as a map of Edges departing from each Vertex. This allows the `IncidentsFrom` and `OutDegree` functions to [look up a list of edges directly given a vertex id](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/9e81045e43342db8a910dfe76729d0b22ffa4e68/include/ignition/math/graph/Graph.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Graph.hh-425:435).

There is no equivalent data structure for storing a list of edges arriving at a given vertex, however. This means that `IncidentsTo` and `InDegree` need to [iterate over all vertices and then all edges](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/9e81045e43342db8a910dfe76729d0b22ffa4e68/include/ignition/math/graph/Graph.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#Graph.hh-425:435) to see if any of those edges arrive at the specified vertex.

I've added a test that illustrates this performance difference for graphs with large numbers of nodes in branch `edgeless_performance_test` (7bf2e007e43e). These test cases instantiates a graph with many vertices and no edges, then call `InDegree` and `OutDegree` for each vertex, expecting 0, since there are no edges. The test case that calls `InDegree` is much slower than `OutDegree`:

~~~
# DirectedEdge
[ RUN      ] GraphTestFixture/0.EdgelessInDegree
[       OK ] GraphTestFixture/0.EdgelessInDegree (936 ms)
[ RUN      ] GraphTestFixture/0.EdgelessOutDegree
[       OK ] GraphTestFixture/0.EdgelessOutDegree (8 ms)
~~~

~~~
# UndirectedEdge
[ RUN      ] GraphTestFixture/1.EdgelessInDegree
[       OK ] GraphTestFixture/1.EdgelessInDegree (1270 ms)
[ RUN      ] GraphTestFixture/1.EdgelessOutDegree
[       OK ] GraphTestFixture/1.EdgelessOutDegree (8 ms)
~~~

For cases when a graph with directed edges represents the kinematics of a multibody system with vertices as Links and edges as Joints, the `IncidentsTo` function is equivalent to `GetParentJoints`, which is used in many places in gazebo physics.

This is an issue of performance not correctness, so it may not be a priority, but I wanted to mention it.
content.html:
The Graph class uses an adjacency list internally to assist with computations. This is stored internally as a map of Edges departing from each Vertex. This allows the IncidentsFrom and OutDegree functions to look up a list of edges directly given a vertex id.

There is no equivalent data structure for storing a list of edges arriving at a given vertex, however. This means that IncidentsTo and InDegree need to iterate over all vertices and then all edges to see if any of those edges arrive at the specified vertex.

I've added a test that illustrates this performance difference for graphs with large numbers of nodes in branch edgeless_performance_test (7bf2e007e43e). These test cases instantiates a graph with many vertices and no edges, then call InDegree and OutDegree for each vertex, expecting 0, since there are no edges. The test case that calls InDegree is much slower than OutDegree:

# DirectedEdge
[ RUN      ] GraphTestFixture/0.EdgelessInDegree
[       OK ] GraphTestFixture/0.EdgelessInDegree (936 ms)
[ RUN      ] GraphTestFixture/0.EdgelessOutDegree
[       OK ] GraphTestFixture/0.EdgelessOutDegree (8 ms)

# UndirectedEdge
[ RUN      ] GraphTestFixture/1.EdgelessInDegree
[       OK ] GraphTestFixture/1.EdgelessInDegree (1270 ms)
[ RUN      ] GraphTestFixture/1.EdgelessOutDegree
[       OK ] GraphTestFixture/1.EdgelessOutDegree (8 ms)

For cases when a graph with directed edges represents the kinematics of a multibody system with vertices as Links and edges as Joints, the IncidentsTo function is equivalent to GetParentJoints, which is used in many places in gazebo physics.

This is an issue of performance not correctness, so it may not be a priority, but I wanted to mention it.

values.title: Feature request: determine if a connected DirectedGraph is a DirectedTree

content.raw:
This could have a function prototype like:

~~~
VertexId DirectedGraph::DirectedTreeRoot(const VertexId &_idGuess = kNullId)
~~~

It would operate on a `DirectedGraph` and return the root of the directed tree if it is found to be a directed tree. If it's not a directed tree it could return `kNullId`. You could pass in a guess for the `VertexId` of the root, which shouldn't affect the accuracy but might speed it up if you already know the root?

There are several properties that must be satisfied for a `DirectedGraph` to also be a directed tree:

* if treated as an `UndirectedGraph`, it should be connected (one island)
* there should be no loops
* the root vertex should have `InDegree() == 0` (no parents) and all other vertices should have `InDegree() == 1` (only one parent)

It could be useful to provide additional functions to test these conditions (connectedness, presence of loops, singular parentage), since we currently have logic for the dart and simbody interfaces in gazebo that identifies kinematic loops and replaces one of the loop joints with a weld constraint.
content.html:
This could have a function prototype like:

VertexId DirectedGraph::DirectedTreeRoot(const VertexId &_idGuess = kNullId)

It would operate on a DirectedGraph and return the root of the directed tree if it is found to be a directed tree. If it's not a directed tree it could return kNullId. You could pass in a guess for the VertexId of the root, which shouldn't affect the accuracy but might speed it up if you already know the root?

There are several properties that must be satisfied for a DirectedGraph to also be a directed tree:

  • if treated as an UndirectedGraph, it should be connected (one island)
  • there should be no loops
  • the root vertex should have InDegree() == 0 (no parents) and all other vertices should have InDegree() == 1 (only one parent)

It could be useful to provide additional functions to test these conditions (connectedness, presence of loops, singular parentage), since we currently have logic for the dart and simbody interfaces in gazebo that identifies kinematic loops and replaces one of the loop joints with a weld constraint.

values.title: Feature request: identify cycles in undirected graph

content.raw:
This is split out from #82, as one of the steps in determining whether a DirectedGraph is a DirectedTree. If a graph represents the kinematics of a multibody system, it is helpful to know if there are cycles in the graph, which represent kinematic loops. Some simulators need to take special steps in order handle models with loops.

This [stackoverflow post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/526331/cycles-in-an-undirected-graph/532951#532951) suggests that a depth-first search can be used to identify cycles in an undirected graph.
content.html:
This is split out from #82, as one of the steps in determining whether a DirectedGraph is a DirectedTree. If a graph represents the kinematics of a multibody system, it is helpful to know if there are cycles in the graph, which represent kinematic loops. Some simulators need to take special steps in order handle models with loops.

This stackoverflow post suggests that a depth-first search can be used to identify cycles in an undirected graph.

values.title: Reconsider using static functions for Rand

content.raw:
I've noticed that all of the functions in `ignition::math::Rand` are static functions. I'm pretty certain this is not thread safe, and it could cause conflicts if different users within the same application want to have control over the seed (which can be useful for various reasons, like using a predetermined seed to get deterministic results for tests).

I would propose that we instead create a class to wrap this functionality, and each instance of the class will manage its own seed, random device, and distribution member independently from all other instances.

If people agree with this idea, I'd be happy to make the necessary changes.
content.html:
I've noticed that all of the functions in ignition::math::Rand are static functions. I'm pretty certain this is not thread safe, and it could cause conflicts if different users within the same application want to have control over the seed (which can be useful for various reasons, like using a predetermined seed to get deterministic results for tests).

I would propose that we instead create a class to wrap this functionality, and each instance of the class will manage its own seed, random device, and distribution member independently from all other instances.

If people agree with this idea, I'd be happy to make the necessary changes.

values.title: Plane Normal and offset incorrectly used by Plane::Side()

content.html:
The Plane constructor defines a plane using a a normal vector and an offset along that vector. For example, Planed plane(Vector3d(1, 0, 0), 0.5); constructs a plane parallel to the Y-Z plane passing through point (0.5, 0, 0).

When I wrote pull request #194 I misunderstood and wrote the following test. It should fail, but it actually passes.

  // Construct an angled vertical plane
  Planed plane(Vector3d(1, 1, 0), 1);

  // 1m^3 box with one corner 1cm away from front side of plane
  {
    Box box(Vector3d(0.51, 0.51, -.5), Vector3d(1.51, 1.51, .5));
    // WRONG, Side should report BOTH_SIDES, not positive side
    EXPECT_EQ(Planed::POSITIVE_SIDE, plane.Side(box));
  }

Here's what the test looks like from the top down. The gray vector is the normal. The red line is the plane. The blue box is the box being tested. The box clearly lies on both sides of the plane, but Plane::Side(Box) reports POSITIVE_SIDE.

It's as if Plane::Side(Box) thinks the plane passes through points (1, 0, 0) and (0, 1, 0), but an offset of 1 along the normal actually puts the plane further out.

values.title: Graph.hh doesn't expose non-const reference to Edges

content.raw:
# Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Checked the Q&A board for common solutions: http://answers.gazebosim.org
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed.
    * Checked that there is not already an Ignition package that provides the described functionality: https://ignitionrobotics.org/libs

# Description 

The [Graph::VertexFromId function](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/e272f076f171fce6be704e822a65a4c0cbecd9d6/include/ignition/math/graph/Graph.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Graph.hh-609:622) has two versions that return a `const` and non-`const` reference to a Vertex. However there is only a `const` version of the [Graph::EdgeFromId function](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/e272f076f171fce6be704e822a65a4c0cbecd9d6/include/ignition/math/graph/Graph.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Graph.hh-674), which makes it hard to modify Edge Data().

Likewise, the [Graph::AdjacentsTo and Graph::AdjacentsFrom functions](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/e272f076f171fce6be704e822a65a4c0cbecd9d6/include/ignition/math/graph/Graph.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Graph.hh-291:383) return non-`const` references to the graph vertices, while the [Graph::IncidentsTo and Graph::IncidentsFrom functions](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/e272f076f171fce6be704e822a65a4c0cbecd9d6/include/ignition/math/graph/Graph.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Graph.hh-425:486) only return `const` references to the graph edges.

# Steps to Reproduce

* Apply the following patch to [GraphUndirected_TEST.cc](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/e272f076f171fce6be704e822a65a4c0cbecd9d6/src/graph/GraphUndirected_TEST.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default):

~~~
diff -r 8372d72d8cf0 src/graph/GraphUndirected_TEST.cc
--- a/src/graph/GraphUndirected_TEST.cc	Tue Feb 12 20:49:41 2019 +0000
+++ b/src/graph/GraphUndirected_TEST.cc	Fri Feb 15 17:44:21 2019 -0800
@@ -365,9 +365,10 @@
   // Change some content and verity it.
   e2.Data() = 5.0;
   e2.SetWeight(6.0);
-  auto edge = graph.EdgeFromId(e2.Id());
+  auto &edge = graph.EdgeFromId(e2.Id());
   EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ(5.0, edge.Data());
   EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ(6.0, edge.Weight());
+  edge.Data() = 7.0;
 
   // Check that the edges point to the right vertices.
   EXPECT_EQ(0u, e0.Vertices().first);
~~~

* Try to build and it will fail to compile.

**Expected behavior:**  

Compile successfully.

**Actual behavior:**

Fails to compile.

**Reproduces how often:** 

always

# Versions

5.0.0 and 6.0.0, Ubuntu

# Additional Information
content.html:
Prerequisites

  • [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    • Checked the Q&A board for common solutions: http://answers.gazebosim.org
    • Checked that your issue isn't already filed.
    • Checked that there is not already an Ignition package that provides the described functionality: https://ignitionrobotics.org/libs

Description

The Graph::VertexFromId function has two versions that return a const and non-const reference to a Vertex. However there is only a const version of the Graph::EdgeFromId function, which makes it hard to modify Edge Data().

Likewise, the Graph::AdjacentsTo and Graph::AdjacentsFrom functions return non-const references to the graph vertices, while the Graph::IncidentsTo and Graph::IncidentsFrom functions only return const references to the graph edges.

Steps to Reproduce

  • Apply the following patch to GraphUndirected_TEST.cc:
diff -r 8372d72d8cf0 src/graph/GraphUndirected_TEST.cc
--- a/src/graph/GraphUndirected_TEST.cc Tue Feb 12 20:49:41 2019 +0000
+++ b/src/graph/GraphUndirected_TEST.cc Fri Feb 15 17:44:21 2019 -0800
@@ -365,9 +365,10 @@
   // Change some content and verity it.
   e2.Data() = 5.0;
   e2.SetWeight(6.0);
-  auto edge = graph.EdgeFromId(e2.Id());
+  auto &edge = graph.EdgeFromId(e2.Id());
   EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ(5.0, edge.Data());
   EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ(6.0, edge.Weight());
+  edge.Data() = 7.0;

   // Check that the edges point to the right vertices.
   EXPECT_EQ(0u, e0.Vertices().first);
  • Try to build and it will fail to compile.

Expected behavior:

Compile successfully.

Actual behavior:

Fails to compile.

Reproduces how often:

always

Versions

5.0.0 and 6.0.0, Ubuntu

Additional Information
